behavior_min_power: On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ within the supported voltage range, the AP operates at full functionality. Operation on 802.3af or lower-class PoE sources is not specified and should be avoided for production use.
On 802.3bt (Class 5) PoE++, the AP operates at full functionality. Lower-class PoE sources are not supported and may prevent the AP from booting.
antenna_connectors: 8× external connectors for detachable 2.4/5 GHz antennas

behavior_min_power: On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ within the supported voltage range, the AP operates at full functionality. Operation on 802.3af or lower-class PoE sources is not specified and should be avoided for production use.

On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ within the supported voltage range, the AP operates at full functionality. Operation on 802.3af or lower-class PoE sources is not specified and should be avoided for production use.
On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ or 12V DC, the AP operates at full functionality. Operation on 802.3af or lower-class PoE sources is not specified and should be avoided for production use.
On 802.3at PoE+, USB is disabled, the 2.4 GHz radio is limited to 2x2 operation, and maximum EIRP is reduced across all bands.
On 802.3af PoE, the 2.4 GHz radio is reduced to 1x1 operation and Ethernet link speed is limited to 1 GbE.
On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ within the supported voltage range, the AP operates at full functionality. Operation on lower-class PoE sources is not specified and should be avoided for production use.
On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+, USB is disabled, LAN2 is disabled, the 2.4 GHz radio is limited to 2x2 operation, and the multi-function radio EIRP is reduced by 3 dB.
On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+, USB is disabled, LAN2 is disabled, the 2.4 GHz radio is limited to 2x2 operation, and the multi-function radio EIRP is reduced by 3 dB.
On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+, the LAN2 PSE port is disabled while the client access radios remain fully functional.
On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+, the LAN2 PSE port is disabled while the client access radios remain fully functional.
On 802.3at PoE+, PSE functionality is disabled, USB is disabled, and maximum transmit power is reduced across all bands.
On DC or 802.3at, AP operates without restrictions. On 802.3af, USB is disabled unless IPM dynamically reduces other features based on power budget.

behavior_min_power: On DC or 802.3at, AP operates without restrictions. On 802.3af, USB is disabled unless IPM dynamically reduces other features based on power budget.

behavior_min_power: On DC or 802.3at/802.3bt, AP operates without restrictions. On 802.3af, USB and at least one Ethernet port are disabled and IPM may reduce other features based on available PoE.

recommended_poe: 802.3at (Class 4) or 802.3bt (Class 5) or DC for unrestricted operation
behavior_min_power: On DC or 802.3at/802.3bt, AP operates without restrictions. On 802.3af, USB and at least one Ethernet port are disabled and IPM may reduce other features based on available PoE.

On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE, the AP operates with its dual radios but disables the secondary Ethernet port when IPM is not used; with IPM enabled, the AP starts unrestricted and may dynamically disable features based on the available PoE budget. Operation on 802.3af (Class 3 or lower) PoE sources is not supported.
antenna_connectors: Six RP-SMA connectors for external 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz antennas

behavior_min_power: On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE with IPM disabled, the AP reduces the 2.4 GHz radio to 1x1; with IPM enabled, the AP starts unrestricted and may dynamically apply feature reductions based on the available PoE budget. Using 802.3at (Class 4) PoE removes these restrictions.

On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE with IPM disabled, the AP reduces the 2.4 GHz radio to 1x1; with IPM enabled, the AP starts unrestricted and may dynamically apply feature reductions based on the available PoE budget. Using 802.3at (Class 4) PoE removes these restrictions.

On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE, the AP operates with both radios enabled but limits the 5 GHz radio to 2x2 operation and disables the USB port; 802.3bt is recommended for full 4x4 performance and full feature availability.
antenna_connectors: Six RP-SMA connectors for external 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz antennas

behavior_min_power: On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE, the AP operates with both radios enabled but limits the 5 GHz radio to 2x2 operation and disables the USB port; 802.3bt is recommended for full 4x4 performance and full feature availability.

On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE, the AP operates with both radios enabled but limits the 5 GHz radio to 2x2 operation and disables the USB port; 802.3bt is recommended for full 4x4 performance and full feature availability.
On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE, both Wi-Fi radios are reduced to 2x2 operation and PoE-out on E2 is disabled; 802.3bt is recommended whenever full 4x4 performance and downstream PoE are required.
antenna_connectors: Four dual-band N-type female connectors for external Wi-Fi antennas plus one N-type female connector for the Bluetooth/Zigbee IoT radio
operating_temp_range: −40°C to +65°C operating; −40°C to +70°C storage; 5% to 93% RH non-condensing; IP66/67

behavior_min_power: On 802.3at (Class 4), the AP-655 operates in a power-restricted mode similar to an AP-635, potentially limiting bands, features, or transmit power.

On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE, USB is disabled and maximum transmit power on all radios is reduced by up to 3 dB; with IPM enabled, additional feature and power reductions may be applied based on available power.
On 802.3at PoE, USB is disabled and maximum transmit power on all radios is reduced by up to 3 dB; with IPM enabled, additional feature and power reductions may be applied based on available power.
On 802.3at PoE, USB is disabled and maximum transmit power on all radios is reduced by up to 3 dB; with IPM enabled, additional feature and power reductions may be applied based on available power.

On 802.3bt (Class 6) PoE, the AP operates without restrictions; operation on a single 802.3af (Class 3 or lower) PoE source is not supported (except for AP staging), and IPM may apply additional feature and power reductions when power is limited.

behavior_min_power: On 802.3at power the AP supports all three Wi-Fi radios (2.4 GHz, 5 GHz, and 6 GHz) plus the BLE/802.15.4 IoT radio in the intended operating mode; 802.3af power would force the radios and IoT features into a heavily reduced configuration and is not recommended for production deployments.

On 802.3at power the AP operates the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz radios and the IoT radio at full performance; 802.3af power would severely limit functionality and is only suitable for discovery or emergency use rather than normal client service.

On 802.3at power the AP brings up the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz radios together with the IoT radio but keeps the software-defined third radio and USB port disabled; 802.3bt power is recommended when you want the SDR radio and USB enabled for full functionality and maximum performance.

On 802.3at power the AP operates its three Wi-Fi radios but may need to disable power-hungry options such as the USB interface and IoT/BLE radio depending on the configured feature set; 802.3bt power is recommended whenever you want all radios and interfaces enabled under full load and at maximum performance.

On 802.3at power the AP can run its tri-radio set with reduced headroom and may need to limit features such as USB or IoT/BLE radio use; 802.3bt power is recommended for full tri-radio throughput, maximum EIRP, and PoE budget, especially in hot outdoor environments.

On 802.3af power the AP can run both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz radios for typical indoor coverage but with a tighter overall power budget; 802.3at power is recommended when you expect higher client density, higher throughput, or want additional headroom for sustained operation at maximum transmit power.

On 802.3af power the AP runs the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz radios and the IoT radio for in-room coverage but has little or no remaining power budget for PoE out; 802.3at power is recommended when you need to power an attached device (such as a phone or IoT hub) from the LAN port while maintaining reliable Wi-Fi service.
ethernet_ports_speed: 3× 10/100/1000BASE-T (1× WAN + 2× LAN, one with PoE out)

behavior_min_power: On 802.3at power the AP supports both Wi-Fi radios at full outdoor performance and meets the typical 20 W power requirement; falling back to 802.3af would not provide sufficient power and is not supported for normal operation.

On 802.3at power the AP runs both Wi-Fi radios and the BLE radio with full outdoor performance and can supply power to an auxiliary device via the secondary Ethernet port; if the available power budget is constrained, PoE-out capability and/or radio performance may need to be reduced.

On 802.3at power the AP operates both the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz radios at full performance with normal feature support; on 802.3af power it will boot but runs in a reduced-function mode (such as limiting certain features or radio capabilities), so 802.3at is recommended for production deployments.
Disables PoE out, disables USB
ethernet_ports_speed: 2x 1 Gig LAN Ports  1x 1 Gig Lan port with 802.3af PoE output  1x Passthrough (RJ45) Port

behavior_min_power: On 802.3bt or DC, all radios/features enabled. On 802.3at, radios active but USB/advanced features disabled. On 802.3af, radios reduced or disabled.
dimensions: 7.8 x 7.8 x 2.1 inches (20 x 20 x 5.3 cm)

operating_temp_range: 32°F to 122°F (0°C to 50°C) operating; –22°F to 158°F (–30°C to 70°C) storage

behavior_min_power: On 802.3bt or DC, all radios/features enabled. On 802.3at, radios active but USB/advanced features disabled. On 802.3af, radios reduced or disabled.
dimensions: 9.5 x 9.5 x 2.0 inches (24 x 24 x 5.1 cm)

behavior_min_power: On 802.3bt (Class 6), operates in quad-radio mode with 4x4 radios on 2.4/5/6 GHz and both 10G uplinks; on 802.3at, operates in tri-radio mode with reduced radio configuration; on 802.3af, all radios are off and the AP is for configuration staging only.

recommended_poe: 802.3bt or DC for full operation with USB
behavior_min_power: On 802.3bt or DC, all radios operate (2x2 2.4 GHz, 4x4 5/6 GHz) with USB enabled; on 802.3at, radios operate with USB disabled; on 802.3af, all radios are off and the AP is for configuration staging only.
operating_temp_range: 32°F to 122°F (0°C to 50°C) operating; -22°F to 158°F (-30°C to 70°C) storage

recommended_poe: 802.3bt or DC for full operation with USB
behavior_min_power: On 802.3bt or DC, all radios operate 4x4 on 2.4/5/6 GHz with USB enabled; on 802.3at, radios remain 4x4 with USB disabled; on 802.3af, all radios are off and the AP is for configuration staging only.
operating_temp_range: 32°F to 122°F (0°C to 50°C) operating; -22°F to 158°F (-30°C to 70°C) storage

behavior_min_power: On 802.3at, all Wi-Fi radios can operate but USB and PoE-out are disabled and some advanced features may be constrained.
On 802.3at, all Wi-Fi radios can operate at 2×2 and Ethernet ports are restricted to 1Gbps
On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+, the AP reduces all radios to 2x2 operation, disables USB, and limits Ethernet link speed to 2.5 GbE. On 802.3af, radios are disabled (staging only, 13.95W max).
Runs at full functionality on 802.3af (Class 3) PoE; no reduced-power mode is documented.

On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE the AP operates with the 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz radios at 2x2 and the 2.5 GbE uplink enabled, but the USB port and PoE-out on LAN1 are disabled; on 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ either the USB port or PoE-out on LAN1 can be enabled.
ethernet_ports_speed: 1× 1/2.5 GbE (RJ45, uplink PoE in) + 3× 1 GbE (RJ45, LAN, one with PoE out)

behavior_min_power: On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE the AP enters reduced-feature mode with both radios limited to 2x2, the uplink limited to 1 GbE, and the USB port disabled; on 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ it supports 4x4 operation with a 2.5 GbE uplink and USB enabled.

On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE the AP enters reduced-feature mode with both radios limited to 2x2, the uplink limited to 1 GbE, and the USB port disabled; on 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ it supports 4x4 operation with a 2.5 GbE uplink and USB enabled.

On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE the AP operates in reduced-power modes with radios limited to up to 2x2, the uplink limited to 1 GbE, and the USB port disabled; on 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ it supports 4x4 operation on both radios with a 2.5 GbE uplink and USB enabled.

On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE the AP operates in reduced-power modes with radios limited to up to 2x2, the uplink limited to 1 GbE, and the USB port disabled; on 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ it supports 4x4 operation on both radios with a 2.5 GbE uplink and USB enabled.
antenna_connectors: 1× RP-TNC antenna port plus smart antenna (DART) connector for external antennas

behavior_min_power: On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE the AP operates in a reduced-feature mode with both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz radios limited to 1x1, the uplink restricted to 1 GbE, and the USB port disabled; on 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ it supports 4x4 on 2.4 GHz with either 8x8 or dual 4x4 operation on 5 GHz and can optionally power the USB port as documented in the datasheet power table.

On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE the AP operates in a reduced-feature mode with both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz radios limited to 1x1, the uplink restricted to 1 GbE, and the USB port disabled; on 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ it supports 4x4 on 2.4 GHz with either 8x8 or dual 4x4 operation on 5 GHz and can optionally power the USB port as documented in the datasheet power table.
antenna_connectors: Smart antenna connector with 8-DART interface for external antennas

behavior_min_power: On 802.3af the AP operates with full radios and features as specified, assuming a full 802.3af power budget is available.
On 802.3af the AP enters low-power mode with PoE-out disabled; client Wi-Fi radios remain active.
On 802.3af the AP runs in low-power mode with 5 GHz reduced to 2x2, 2.5G uplink downshifted to 1G, scanning and IoT radios disabled, and reduced max transmit power.
On 802.3at the AP operates with full 4x4 radios and dedicated scanning/BLE radios enabled; lower power is not recommended for production use.
On 802.3at the AP operates with full 4x4 radios and external antenna support; minimum PoE should be provisioned as 802.3at for full performance.
Runs at full functionality on 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+; no reduced-power mode is documented.
On 802.3at the tri-radio AP operates with full 4x4 2.4/5/6 GHz radios and dedicated scanning/BLE radios; minimum PoE should be provisioned as 802.3at for full Wi-Fi 6E capability.
dimensions: Similar physical envelope to MR56; tri-band indoor chassis (see datasheet for exact values).
weight: Approx. 1.0 kg (see datasheet for exact value)

behavior_min_power: On 802.3af the outdoor AP operates in a reduced-power mode intended for basic coverage; 802.3at is recommended for full performance and temperature range.
dimensions: Open-air, IP67 enclosure (see datasheet for exact dimensions)
weight: Outdoor housing (see datasheet for exact weight)
operating_temp_range: Extended outdoor range (approx. -40°C to +55°C; see datasheet for exact limits)

behavior_min_power: On 802.3af the outdoor AP runs in low-power mode with reduced radio performance; 802.3at is recommended to enable full transmit power and features.
dimensions: Compact outdoor enclosure (see datasheet for exact dimensions)
weight: Outdoor housing (see datasheet for exact weight)
operating_temp_range: Extended outdoor range (approx. -40°C to +55°C; see datasheet for exact limits)

behavior_min_power: No PoE out, disables USB
Full functionality on 802.3at (PoE+)
On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE, the AP operates with both radios enabled but may reduce transmit power and disable the USB port; 802.3at is recommended for unrestricted operation.
On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE, the USB port is disabled and the 6 GHz radio may reduce transmit power; 802.3at enables unrestricted tri-band performance.
On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE, the USB port is disabled and the 6 GHz radio may reduce transmit power; 802.3at enables unrestricted tri-band performance.
On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE, the AP cannot power its downstream Ethernet ports and may disable the USB port; 802.3at is required for full wallplate switch functionality.

recommended_poe: 802.3at (Class 4) required; 802.3bt recommended for maximum 6 GHz performance
behavior_min_power: On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE, the AP enables all three radios but may reduce 6 GHz transmit power; 802.3bt provides the full power budget for maximum 4x4 6 GHz operation.

On 802.3at, all three Wi-Fi radios (2.4/5/6 GHz) operate at full Tx power with 2x2 MIMO. On 802.3af, radios still operate at full Tx power but are limited to 1x1 MIMO, reducing spatial stream capacity.
With 802.3at or the included passive 60W injector, all radios operate at full Tx power with 2x2 MIMO. Lower PoE classes are not specified as supported for full operation.

On 802.3af, all three Wi-Fi radios (2.4/5/6 GHz) are disabled for client service and only scanning is supported, USB off. On 802.3at, 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz radios operate at full power while 6 GHz runs at reduced Tx power (~15 dBm) with scanning and USB enabled. On 802.3bt, all radios operate at full power with scanning and USB enabled.

On 802.3af, all three Wi-Fi radios (2.4/5/6 GHz) are disabled for client service and only scanning is supported, USB off. On 802.3at, 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz radios operate at full power while 6 GHz runs at reduced Tx power (~15 dBm) with scanning and USB enabled. On 802.3bt, all radios operate at full power with scanning and USB enabled.

On 802.3bt or 2×802.3at or DC, radios operate at full Tx power with 4x4 chains and USB enabled. On 802.3at or 2×802.3af, all radios remain active but run at reduced Tx power (~17 dBm) with USB disabled.
On 802.3at or 2×802.3af, all radios remain active but run at reduced Tx power (~17 dBm) with USB disabled.

On 802.3bt or 2×802.3at or DC, radios operate at full Tx power with 4x4 chains and USB enabled. On 802.3at or 2×802.3af, all radios remain active but run at reduced Tx power (~17 dBm) with USB disabled.
antenna_connectors: 4× RP-SMA (dual-band) + 4 external permanently attached tri-band antennas

behavior_min_power: On 802.3bt or 2×802.3at or DC, all client radios operate at maximum Tx power with 4x4 chains and USB enabled. On 802.3at or 2×802.3af, client radios operate at reduced Tx power (~17 dBm) with 2x2 chains and USB disabled; 2.4/5/6 GHz radios and the fourth radio remain operational.

On 802.3bt or 2×802.3at or DC, all client radios operate at maximum Tx power with 4x4 chains and USB enabled. On 802.3at or 2×802.3af, client radios operate at reduced Tx power (~17 dBm) with 4x4 chains but lower Tx power and USB disabled.
On 802.3af the AP can run 2x2 on two bands plus a 1x1 scan radio in tri-band mode; power is sufficient for full intended functionality.
On 802.3af the AP supports a reduced single-radio mode primarily for cloud connectivity; on 802.3at full tri-band 2x2 operation is available.
Same PoE behavior as AP37: full function on 802.3bt; reduced functionality on 802.3at; radios disabled with 802.3af.
Same PoE behavior as AP37/AP36: full function on 802.3bt; reduced functionality on 802.3at; radios disabled with 802.3af.
antenna_connectors: Two pluggable external antenna connectors: 2.4/5 GHz (4-pin) and 6 GHz (6-pin)

behavior_min_power: PoE PD via Eth0: full functionality on 802.3bt; on 802.3at functionality is reduced; on 802.3af all Wi-Fi radios are disabled and the AP provides only cloud connectivity.

On 802.3af, only a single 1x1 radio plus BLE and scan are enabled to signal that the AP needs more power. On 802.3at, any two radios can be 4x4 or the AP can run three bands with some radios reduced to 2x2; USB and PoE-out are disabled. On 802.3bt, full tri-band 4x4 plus scan, BLE, PoE-out on Eth1, and USB are enabled.
ethernet_ports_speed: 2×1GbE (PoE-in on Eth0, PoE-out on Eth1 when powered by 802.3bt)

behavior_min_power: Same PoE behavior as AP45: reduced radios and no USB or PoE-out on 802.3at; on 802.3af only a single low-power radio plus BLE and scan operate.
ethernet_ports_speed: 2×1GbE (PoE-in on Eth0, PoE-out on Eth1 when powered by 802.3bt)
antenna_connectors: Two pluggable connectors: 2.4/5 GHz (4-pin), 6 GHz + scan (6-pin)

behavior_min_power: On 802.3at, any two radios can run 4x4 or all three bands with some radios reduced to 2x2; USB is disabled but scan, dual IoT radios, UWB, GPS, and both 10GbE uplinks remain enabled. On 802.3af, Wi-Fi radios are disabled and the AP provides cloud connectivity only.

Same PoE behavior as AP47: 802.3bt enables full tri-band 4x4 with all IoT, UWB, GPS, and dual 10GbE; on 802.3at one or more radios may be reduced to 2x2 and USB is disabled; on 802.3af radios are disabled for cloud connectivity only.
Same PoE behavior as AP47: full functionality on 802.3bt; reduced radio chains and no USB on 802.3at; on 802.3af Wi-Fi radios are disabled and the AP provides cloud connectivity only.
antenna_connectors: Three pluggable connectors: 2.4/5/6 GHz (6-pin), 6 GHz + scan (6-pin), 5 GHz (4-pin)

behavior_min_power: On 802.3af the AP can support full tri-band 2x2 plus scan; it is designed to operate within the 802.3af power budget.
operating_temp_range: -40°C to 55°C (with solar load); -40°C to 65°C (without solar load)

behavior_min_power: PoE PD via Eth0: on 802.3at the AP operates with full functionality; on 802.3af all radios are disabled and the AP provides only cloud connectivity.
operating_temp_range: -40°C to 55°C (with solar load); -40°C to 65°C (without solar load)

behavior_min_power: Same PoE behavior as AP66: full function on 802.3at; on 802.3af all radios are disabled for cloud connectivity only.
operating_temp_range: -40°C to 55°C (with solar load); -40°C to 65°C (without solar load)

behavior_min_power: N/A

On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE the AP supports reduced-power operation where either the 5 GHz radio is limited to 4x4 with USB and Zigbee/BLE disabled or the secondary Ethernet port and USB are disabled to allow 8x8 operation on 5 GHz; on 802.3af (Class 3) PoE both Wi-Fi radios are disabled. Full functionality with both radios at maximum configuration, USB and IoT enabled is only documented for DC power or PoH/uPoE.
On 802.3bt PoE++ the AP operates at full performance. Lower-class PoE sources are not supported and may prevent the AP from booting.
On 802.3bt PoE++ the AP operates at full performance. Lower-class PoE sources are not supported and may prevent the AP from booting.

recommended_poe: 802.3bt PoE++ for full performance and PoE output; 802.3at PoE+ for AP-only operation
behavior_min_power: On 802.3bt PoE++, the AP and PoE-out port operate without restrictions. On 802.3at PoE+, the AP radios operate normally but PoE-out is disabled or limited to stay within the available power budget.

recommended_poe: 802.3at PoE+ for AP plus PoE output; 802.3af PoE for AP-only operation
behavior_min_power: On 802.3at PoE+, the AP and PoE-out port operate normally. On 802.3af PoE, the AP radios operate but PoE-out is disabled to stay within the available power budget.
Designed for 802.3af PoE; the AP operates normally within the supported voltage range. PoE sources with very low power budgets may cause boot or stability issues under heavy traffic.
On 802.3at PoE+ the AP operates at full performance. 802.3af-class or low-power PoE sources may prevent the AP from powering on or staying stable under load.
On 802.3at PoE+ the AP operates at full performance. 802.3af-class or low-power PoE sources may prevent the AP from powering on or staying stable under load.
On 802.3at PoE+ the AP operates at full performance. 802.3af-class or undersized PoE sources may prevent the AP from booting or remaining stable.
On 802.3bt PoE++ the AP operates at full performance. Lower-class PoE sources are not supported and may prevent the AP from powering on reliably.
The AP does not list lower-class PoE sources as being supported, and may not work properly or at all with less than 802.3bt (60 W) PoE.
weight: 3.3 kg (7.3 lb) (device only), 4.3 kg (9.5 lb) (device with mount)
antenna_connectors: None (internal directional antennas switchable between 15 dBi, 50° x 50° and 11 dBi, 90° x 90° operation)

behavior_min_power: none

On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ within the supported voltage range, the AP operates at full functionality with all radios enabled. Operation on 802.3af or lower-class PoE sources is not specified and should be avoided for production use.
On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+, Wi-Fi operates at 2.4GHz 2x2, 5GHz 4x4, 6GHz 2x2 with wired uplink at 2.5 GbE. Scanning Radio, IoT Radio, Eth1, and USB port are disabled.

On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ within the supported voltage range, the AP operates at full functionality with all radios enabled. Operation on 802.3af or lower-class PoE sources is not specified and should be avoided for production use.
On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+, Wi-Fi operates at 2.4GHz 2x2, 5GHz 2x2, 6GHz 2x2 with wired uplink at 5 GbE. Eth1 (downlink) with PSE and USB port are disabled.
ethernet_ports_speed: 1× 10 GbE (RJ45, PoE) or SFP/SFP+ Combo + 1× 1 GbE (RJ45, uplink/downlink)

behavior_min_power: On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+, Wi-Fi operates at 2.4GHz 2x2, 5GHz 2x2, 6GHz 2x2 with wired uplink at 5 GbE. Eth1 (downlink) with PSE and USB port are disabled.
ethernet_ports_speed: 1× 10 GbE (RJ45, PoE) or SFP/SFP+ Combo + 1× 1 GbE (RJ45, uplink/downlink)

behavior_min_power: Runs at full functionality on 802.3af (Class 3) PoE; no reduced-power mode is documented.
On 802.3af (Class 3) or 802.3at (Class 4) PoE, the AP operates with reduced power budget and PoE-out on downlink ports disabled compared with operation on 802.3bt/PoH/uPoE.
ethernet_ports_speed: 1× 1 GbE (RJ45, PoE in) + 4× 1 GbE (RJ45, one with PoE out)

behavior_min_power: On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE, all four downlink Ethernet ports and IoT radios are enabled but PoE-out on LAN ports is disabled compared with operation on 802.3bt/PoH/uPoE.
ethernet_ports_speed: 1× 1/2.5/5 GbE (RJ45, PoE in) + 4× 1/2.5 GbE (RJ45, two with PoE out)

behavior_min_power: Runs at full functionality on 802.3af (Class 3) PoE; no reduced-power mode is documented.
Runs at full functionality on 802.3af (Class 3) PoE; no reduced-power mode is documented.
On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE, the secondary Ethernet port, USB interface and onboard IoT radio are disabled and transmit power is reduced compared with operation on 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+.

On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE, the AP operates with the 5 GbE uplink enabled but disables the secondary 1 GbE Ethernet port and USB port and reduces 6 GHz transmit power compared with operation on 802.3bt/PoH/uPoE.
On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE, the secondary Ethernet port, USB interface and IoT radio are disabled and transmit power is reduced compared with operation on 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+.
On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE, the AP operates with the 5 GbE uplink enabled but disables the secondary 1 GbE and USB ports and may reduce transmit power compared with operation on 802.3bt/PoH/uPoE.
On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE, the AP reduces transmit power and disables the secondary Ethernet and USB ports and some IoT functionality compared with operation on 802.3bt/PoH/uPoE.

On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE the AP operates with both radios limited to 2x4 streams and the second Ethernet port, onboard IoT radio and USB port disabled; on 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ full 4x4 operation with the second Ethernet port, IoT and USB enabled is supported.

On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE the AP operates in reduced-power mode with the secondary Ethernet port, USB port and Zigbee/BLE IoT radio disabled and reduced transmit power on all bands; full functionality including maximum transmit power and all interfaces enabled requires 802.3bt (Class 5) PoE++ or DC power.
On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE the AP operates with reduced power and USB (and IoT radio where present on T350 variants) disabled; on 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ the AP supports full functionality.
On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE the AP operates with reduced power, USB disabled and the integrated BLE/802.15.4 IoT radio disabled; on 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ the AP supports full functionality.
On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE the AP operates with reduced power, USB disabled and the IoT radio (where present on the model) disabled; on 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ the AP supports full functionality.

On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ the AP operates with reduced functionality: the secondary Ethernet port remains enabled but PoE-out (PSE) on that port is disabled while onboard IoT and USB remain enabled; higher-power 802.3bt PoE++, PoH or AC input is required for full PSE capability with all features enabled.
ethernet_ports_speed: 1× 1/2.5 GbE (RJ45, PoE in) + 1× 1 GbE (RJ45, PoE out PSE) + 1× 1/10 GbE SFP/SFP+ (fiber)

behavior_min_power: On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+ the AP operates with reduced functionality: the secondary Ethernet port remains enabled but PoE-out (PSE) on that port is disabled while onboard IoT and USB (where applicable) remain enabled; higher-power 802.3bt PoE++, PoH or AC input is required for full PSE capability with all features enabled.
ethernet_ports_speed: 1× 1/2.5 GbE (RJ45, PoE in) + 1× 1 GbE (RJ45, PoE out PSE) + 1× 1/10 GbE SFP/SFP+ (fiber)

behavior_min_power: On 802.3af or 802.3at PoE the AP operates with reduced transmit power and the USB port disabled; full functionality with higher transmit power and USB enabled is only supported using 48V DC power.

On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE the AP operates in reduced-power mode with the USB port disabled and reduced transmit power on all bands; full functionality with maximum transmit power and USB enabled requires 802.3bt (Class 5) PoE++ or DC power.

On 802.3at (Class 4) PoE the AP operates in reduced-power mode with the USB port disabled and reduced transmit power on all bands; full functionality with maximum transmit power and USB enabled requires 802.3bt (Class 5) PoE++ or DC power.
On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE the AP reduces 5 GHz to 2x2, disables the USB port, and disables the secondary Ethernet port compared with 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+, which provides full functionality.
On 802.3af (Class 3) PoE the AP reduces 5 GHz to 2x2, disables the USB port, and disables the secondary Ethernet port compared with 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+, which provides full functionality.
Fully functional over 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+; capable of reduced-power operation on 802.3af.
dimensions: 165 mm x 180 mm x 47 mm (6.5 in x 7 in x 1.8 in)

behavior_min_power: Fully functional over 802.3at (Class 4) PoE+; capable of reduced-power operation on 802.3af.
dimensions: 165 mm x 180 mm x 47 mm (6.5 in x 7 in x 1.8 in)
